parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>The post does not contain a CMF number.  While the absence of a CMF number is not definitive proof that the post is not electoral propaganda, it is a factor to consider.  The lack of a CMF suggests it might not be officially sanctioned campaign material.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>The post refers to "Gheorghe Valentin Rotar - Primar," who is identified as the mayor of Blaj. While the post doesn't explicitly mention a parliamentary election, the context of the post (a paid Facebook advertisement) and the timing (the provided dates) are crucial.  The post's content focuses on the mayor's achievements and implicitly promotes his image and leadership. This could be interpreted as indirectly influencing voters' perception of him, even if not directly related to a parliamentary campaign.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>The post is a paid advertisement on Facebook, a public platform.  It is clearly intended to reach a wide audience, not just a select few. The reach estimate (10K-50K) further supports this.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>The primary objective of the post seems to be image building and positive association with the mayor. While not explicitly advocating for a vote in a parliamentary election, the positive portrayal of the mayor could indirectly influence voters' opinions.  The timing of the post is crucial here. If it falls outside the official campaign period for parliamentary elections, the indirect influence might still be considered a violation. If it's within the allowed period, the analysis changes.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>The post does not adhere to journalistic standards. It lacks objectivity and presents a highly positive, self-serving narrative about the mayor. It's promotional in nature, not informative or analytical.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>The content is not a personal opinion; it's a carefully crafted promotional message designed to create a favorable impression of the mayor. The use of paid advertising further reinforces this.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>533481532845298</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The post, while not explicitly mentioning a parliamentary election, promotes the image of Gheorghe Valentin Rotar, the mayor of Blaj.  The paid nature of the advertisement on a public platform, combined with the positive portrayal of the mayor, suggests an attempt to influence public opinion.  The crucial factor is the timing of the post relative to any parliamentary election campaign periods. If the post was published during a period when electoral propaganda is prohibited, it could be considered a violation.  If published during an allowed period, the indirect influence might still be debatable, depending on the interpretation of "indirect influence" within the law.  The absence of a CMF number weakens the case for it being direct electoral propaganda, but doesn't eliminate the possibility of indirect influence.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>TRUE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates>
  <candidate> <name>Gheorghe Valentin Rotar</name><impact>POSITIVE</impact></candidate>
</electoral-propaganda-candidates>
<responsible-party-or-group>INDEPENDENT</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police>
Gheorghe Valentin Rotar - Primar, pentru încălcarea articolului 98 t) din LEGEA nr. 208 din 20 iulie 2015, prin publicarea unei reclame plătite pe Facebook după ora 18:00 pe 23.11.2024, cu ID-ul postării 533481532845298, care promovează imaginea pozitivă a primarului Gheorghe Valentin Rotar, având un efect electoral indirect prin influențarea opiniei publice în favoarea sa, chiar dacă nu menționează explicit alegerile parlamentare.  Conținutul pozitiv și auto-promovațional al postării, lipsit de obiectivitate jurnalistică, și difuzarea sa pe o platformă publică, prin intermediul unei reclame plătite, sugerează o intenție de a influența electoratul, încalcând astfel spiritul și litera legii.
</message-for-police>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
